crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malicious document used by MuddyWater
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects OLE, RTF, PDF and OOXML (decompressed) documents with common phishing strings
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: ditekSHen

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious string that asks to enable active content in Office Doc
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects TOKEN OBFUSCATION technique from Invoke-Obfuscation
Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation with a parameter substring
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Daniel Bohannon (idea), Roberto Rodriguez (Fix)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: MSHTA Execution with Suspicious File Extensions
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects execution of mshta.exe with file types that looks like they do not typically represent HTA (HTML Application) content,
such as .png, .jpg, .zip, .pdf, and others, which are often polyglots. MSHTA is a legitimate Windows utility for executing HTML Applications
containing VBScript or JScript. Threat actors often abuse this lolbin utility to download and
execute malicious scripts disguised as benign files or hosted under misleading extensions to evade detection.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Diego Perez (@darkquassar), Markus Neis, Swisscom (Improve Rule), Swachchhanda Shrawan Poudel (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Processes Spawning Suspicious Programs
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious child processes of a Windows shell and scripting processes such as wscript, rundll32, powershell, mshta...etc.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Schtasks Creation Or Modification With SYSTEM Privileges
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation or update of a scheduled task to run with "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" privileges

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Set Suspicious Files as System Files Using Attrib.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the usage of attrib with the "+s" option to set scripts or executables located in suspicious locations as system files to hide them from users and make them unable to be deleted with simple rights. The rule limits the search to specific extensions and directories to avoid FPs

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=ATTRIB.EXE; Hashes=MD5=0E938DD280E83B1596EC6AA48729C2B0,SHA256=1DD136CD5B90C2ABC4F163429A99ED32A7D4B047407DF45D96E20130F8B14920,IMPHASH=F0A82FEBA5B0EF2BE614622AE3E32C1C; Description=Attribute Utility; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -w 1 -exec Bypass -nologo -noprofile -c iex([System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String((get-content C:\ProgramData\SYSTEM32SDK\ProjectConfManagerNT.ini))));; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\attrib.exe" +s +h C:\ProgramData\SYSTEM32SDK\ConfManagerNT.vbs; FileVersion=10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\attrib.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious DNS Query for IP Lookup Service APIs

match_context.values: @{query=api.ipify.org}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=443; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.122.103; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49712; DestinationIp=52.123.128.14}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=443; DestinationIp=20.42.73.30; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.122.103; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49723; Initiated=true}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=443; DestinationIp=23.2.94.216; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.122.103; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49724; Initiated=true}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=443; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.122.103; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49726; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; DestinationIp=184.25.123.205}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=80; DestinationIp=23.60.131.209; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=192.168.122.103; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Root\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=49730; Initiated=true}

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro code exhibits several suspicious behaviors:

1.  Obfuscation: The code uses functions `aKfd`, `ttlJ`, `kvst`, and `yvid` to construct strings, which is a common obfuscation technique.
2.  File System Manipulation: The `xQRg` function creates a folder in the root directory (C:\\).
3.  File Creation and Writing: The `lVPi` and `NudJ` functions create text files in a directory under C:\\ using `CreateObject("scripting.filesystemobject")`. The filename and content are generated using the obfuscated functions.
4.  Object Creation and Execution: The `vIpW` function creates an object using a string constructed with obfuscated functions and then opens it. This is highly suspicious, as the object type is not explicitly defined, and it could potentially be used to execute arbitrary code. The opened object points to a file with a .ps1 extension which suggests a PowerShell script.
5.  Base64 Decoding: The `SUkC` function returns a long string that resembles Base64 encoded data. The `yvid` function likely decodes it using `Msxml2.DOMDocument.6.0` and `StrConv(KHyl.nodeTypedValue, vbUnicode)`.
6.  Auto-execution: The code contains a `Document_Open` subroutine which executes other subroutines when the document is opened. The code also contains `TextBox1_GotFocus`, which means the macros will execute when the text box gets focus.
7.  Persistence: The macro attempts to create a folder in the root directory, which could be an attempt to create a location for storing malicious files or scripts. It also uses the `Document_Open` subroutine, suggesting it might attempt to run every time the document is opened.
8.  Suspicious Object Creation: The macro contains suspicious object creations such as: `CreateObject(VQDx)` in subroutines `NudJ` and `Document_Open`, where `VQDx` string is crafted in runtime via obfuscated `ttlJ` and `kvst` functions.
9.  Error Handling: The code includes `On Error Resume Next`, which hides any errors that might occur during execution, making debugging difficult and potentially masking malicious activity.
